data.title: Pinter’s wife delighted to be a Dame
data.meta_description: Fourteen years after her husband Harold Pinter rejected a knighthood, Lady Antonia Fraser is appointed a dame for services to literature in the New Year Honours.  Lady Antonia, 78, is the bestselling
data.text:
Fourteen years after her husband Harold Pinter rejected a knighthood, Lady Antonia Fraser is appointed a dame for services to literature in the New Year Honours.

Lady Antonia, 78, is the bestselling author of biographies of Marie Antoinette and Mary Queen of Scots, as well as Must You Go?, an account of her 34-year love affair with Pinter, who died in 2008.

Lady Antonia, who was appointed CBE in 1999, said that despite his own stance the playwright, who was appointed Companion of Honour and awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature, would have approved of her honour.

“He turned down a knighthood because he said ‘I could not make the sort of speeches I make and be introduced as Sir Harold’. But he was
